intro: Vaccinium lorentzii, commonly known as the Lorentz huckleberry, is a low-growing evergreen shrub native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like blueberries and cranberries. The plant produces small, dark blue berries that are typically edible and have a tart flavor. It thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in moist, shaded environments such as forests and streamside areas. Vaccinium lorentzii plays an important ecological role by providing food for wildlife and supporting local biodiversity.
